lesson_theme: Morning routines and time management at work
transcript_text:
Podcast Host (Maya): Welcome back! Today we’re talking morning routines that set the tone for your day.
Guest (Leo): Yesterday I hit snooze twice and got stuck in traffic. By the time I reached the office, I was on autopilot.
Maya: Same here—back-to-back meetings can be a real time-suck. My go-to fix is batching emails in one block.
Leo: Nice. I also clear the decks before lunch—five minutes to close tabs and tidy notes. It cuts friction.
Maya: My rule of thumb: if a task takes two minutes, do it in one go.
Leo: I stumbled upon a great idea last week: schedule a ten-minute pep talk with myself to check in with goals.
Maya: Love it. If you carve out 25 minutes for deep work, you’ll avoid getting sidetracked by the social scroll.
Leo: True. I’ve doubled down on phone limits because brain fog hits me mid-morning.
Maya: If you push back on unnecessary pings, you’ll protect focus.
Leo: Exactly. And if a meeting has no agenda, I pull the plug.
Maya: That’s bold—but fair. Quick note: sometimes guests overshare—TMI—so we trim that.
Leo: When the plan clicks, it’s a light-bulb moment. We outline a game plan, work, and wrap up early.
Maya: If I leave earlier, I’ll avoid traffic; if not, I’ll call it a day at six.
Leo: This week I have started standing check-ins. Yesterday we touched base with design; it was more productive than chat.
Maya: Great. One last thing: tiny progress matters—tiny wins stack up.
Leo: Agreed. Okay, let’s run with it and close here.
